Mac
I have read articles concerning these types of people being attracted to military service. One of the hazards of an all vounteer military.

Without allying myself with any of these groups I'd still note they form because of their perception of the increasingly militarized nature of our "police state", a reaction, not a cause. Generalizing from the statements of a few fringe wing-nuts to characterize all firearms enthusiasts as crazed anarchists indicates paranoia equal to that you ascribe. Lastly, perhaps you ought to investigate the stance of those who wear the uniforms of the services who defend our nation, and see how they feel. I'd wager you'd be in for a shocking disappointment.

You realize that if all these armed groups were even a tiny fraction as violent or racist as you accuse them of, there would be an enormous body count, right? Do you ever think at all before you post? If I really thought someone was heavily armed and mentally unstable I wouldn't spend 40 hours/wk insulting them, but that's just me.

Charles has laid out, very methodically, a lot for us all to chew on.

America's Patriot Group problem isn't merely a worry. These people not only pose the obvious danger of insurgence, but they also are causing our nation to become more and more like a police state.

How many Timothy McVeighs are there among these 1,274 groups? How many Yeagers are out there carrying concealed weapons? How many of them have multiple weapons? How many have a weapons cache? I recently read a report on the explosion in the number of hate groups in California and the Midwest. These racists are armed. Some states allow teachers to carry concealed weapons in schools without the parents knowing about it. Are any of them "patriot" group members?

The Office of Homeland Security was established in response to the 9/11 attacks. We've seen our civil rights curtailed a little more each year, even though Al Qaeda has been vanquished for the most part. Are we keeping it because of these homegrown terrorist groups? When these crazies decide to sound the call to arms, how will the government respond? How will the crazies react?

How to clean up the mess that is para-military patriot groups is a problem we need to solve now. If a gun control bill is passed, it must include a limit to the number of weapons and ammunition one is allowed to own. If our dysfunctional Congress doesn't pass gun legislation now, then our president must have the courage to use his executive power and act before it's too late.

I think that the rules of large cannon ownership are that you can own and shoot any size as long as it was designed and built before 1896 (not sure of date) and is a muzzle loader. Finding a place to shoot, and the expense of buying the gunpowder to fire an 8 inch Parrot gun from Civil War days might be an obstacle.

...then again, 'Spacedancer' suggested earlier that Ms. Smith's experience might better be considered chemicallly-induced, which for some would mean an artificially-induced sense of euphoria, rather than true joy.

Interesting observations on the Smith article. I would point out, however, that St. Thomas was an apologist for the church, and that his reasoning must be taken in that light. He has an ulterior motive. Given his assumption that the Bible is the word of God, all his reasoning, acute as it seems at times, is merely an extrapolation of that assumption.
I would also take issue with the notion that one takes joy in love, human or otherwise. Perhaps, it is rather that joy and love are separate and distinct experiences, or rather emotions, and that to conflate the two only confuses the discussion. Not making a clear distinction between emotion and reason and how, as we know today, reason follows and justifies emotion rather than controls or conditions, is a further and serious limitation to both their arguments.
I would support Smith's argument over St. Thomas's, though. She may not be as rigorous a thinker as he, but lacking the ulterior motive and his limited awareness of psychology, and coming from and looking critically at her own experience gives her assessment a validity the good saint could only pray for.
But armed and potentially quite dangerous hue and cry.

The rich who understand your point are the true danger. Our slide into a right-wing tyranny is aided by people like you and them, who just accept that "as much as they complain, they'll abide by the law" and keep their protests to their first amendment zones.
How do you know that they are law abiding?

Uh huh.  Chicken hawks they are, one and all.  They love talking tough, but in the end, as much as they complain, they'll abide by the law.  A truly law-abiding gun owner doesn't let loose whenever a law passes that he doesn't like.  This is all nothing more than hue and cry.

Yeah, I agree. Drug induced joy doesn't necessarily lack authenticity. The experience of "natural" joy is probably chemically similar to drug induced joy, right?  The human experience of joy is a fact, and one trigger, drugs, shouldn't be automatically devalued. Is Tylenol induced freedom-from-headache less "authentic" than natural freedom-from-headache? On the other hand, there may be good reasons to value some sources of joy over others.

My experience of Joy was meaningful just by the existance of the experience. It to was drug induced but a three day wonder that I can still experience by fond remberance.

This experience has actually brought me through many a crisis. It also has been a bond for the 4 of us that were involved. Yes, I would choose joy over pleasure every time but how often do you know in advance what will cause joy?
We need to reinstate the fairness doctrine.  We have gone totally off the rails as a country when it comes to what is considered "news."

And we are implementing controls on ammonium nitrate fertilizer
http://cnsnews.com/news/article/fertilizer-control-dhs-creates-ammonium-...
Just what qualifies a person to labeled an "analyst" by the big media outlets? A penchant for rattling on?

So, a Fox news analyst feels justified in stating that the Second Amendent gives "patriots" the right "to shoot tyrants if they take over the government." Timothy McVeigh and Terry Nichols shared the same belief.

McVeigh worked the gun show circuit where the "patriot movement" spread their poison. He took it to heart and expanded the definition to include anything associated with the federal government. That's why he saw the 168 people he murdered and the 450 he injured in Oklamoma City as nothing more than collateral damage.

The Alfred P. Murrah Building represented the tyranny of the government and he felt justified in blowing it up. He used the word "tyranny" again and again in his writings. He believed he was a "patriot" until his death and showed no remorse at his execution.

Fox News analysts like the judge inflame these sentiments. In the name of patriotism, they promote insurrection and an armed citizenry.

The flu shot is 62% effective this season, according to the CDC. You can get sick from the flu even after you've had the shot, or due to the shot.
I have never had a flu shot. I don't get the flu. The last time I had it was after a hospital stay.

We do a lot of things that weaken our immune response. There are things we can do to boost our immune system. There are lots of common sense things we can do to avoid getting sick. See my response to Bosco regarding tech things we will soon be able to do.

I am all for flu shots for those whose immune system is compromised and the elderly. My 98 year old grandma and my mom get theirs each year. My husband, daughter, and I do fine without.

That is how the quote is given in Wikipedia.

However, Semmes was talking about the practice of nations licensing privateers, privately owned and operated commerce raiders. It was outlawed at about that time, and Semmes spoke in support of the new law. His was the general opinion.

The parenthetical insertion by an editor of "Commerce raider" is incorrect. He meant "privateer" and not what he later did himself.

Semmes was an officer of the Confederate Navy, and his ship was a commissioned naval ship. That is the opposite of what he condemned, a private person and a privately owned ship with a "letter of marque and reprisal" authorizing it to act as a private commerce raider, a privateer.

Thank you, Tim B. I thought I was the only one calling for a ban on semi-automatic weapons. All the talk is around defining "assault" weapons and limiting magazine capacity while ignoring the one commonality in all of the weapons used in these mass killings: semi-automatic technology. The ability to fire repeated rounds as quickly as the trigger can be pulled is not necessary for either personal protection or for hunting.

Automatic weapons are already banned, a restriction that is not seen as violating the second amendment. Therefore, drawing the line somewhere below semi-automatic weapons would also not be in violation. Six round revolving chamber handguns should be perfectly adequate for personal protection and bolt action hunting rifles are capable of bringing down any prey. Society should not be held captive by hunters wanting the convenience of not having to manually eject and chamber after each shot or the paranoid citizen who lives in fear of being confronted by an armed mob (or a tyrannical government). Such legislation would not eliminate gun violence (no law eliminates crime), but, over time, through enforcement and attrition, we may be able to join the rest of the civilized world where gun atrocities are a rare abomination not an accepted consequence of an obsession with killing machines.

I watched the unedited video by James Yeager, who says he won't put up with it, and if things go any further he said "I am going to start killing people".

How many more unstable, delusional people are going to be allowed to possess military style semi-automatic weapons, weapons designed for the express purpose of killing other human beings? How can we absolutely determine who is unstable and who is not when guns are sold?

One commenter says that extreme gun rights advocates are probably just blowing off steam and in the end are law abiding. From Yeager's inflammatory video, I see no evidence of anything remotely rational. Yeager is convinced that a civil war is coming. Unstable people possessing lethal weapons are a present danger for all except for those who they see as part of their own tribe. How many more Sandy Hook shootings is our government going to allow by not taking decisive actions?

I read today that the newly proposed gun regulations may not even include an assault weapons plan. Why was Australia able to enact stricter gun regulations after its last mass killing? We need leaders with the courage to stand up and say what is right, that the safety of the many outweighs the extraordinary selfishness of the few.

I have owned guns and shot them, all single shot rifles. I never had an inclination to blow anything to bits, and have no idea why semi automatic weapons would ever be needed.
I hope the ganders and geese watch out for those SKEET shooters in the area.

Walter, Rima and the rest of you. Do yourselves a big favor and perhaps get some reality into your minds on this issue.

Just pull a few records and see how many violent crimes or mass shootings are committed by legal and lawful gun owners.

Most violent crimes are committed by criminals or people with some level of mental instability and most are with illegal weapons or weapons obtained illegally.

So, before one starts going after people who go through the relatively lenghtly processes most States require to get and own a gun LEGALLY, concentrate on how to manage the criminal elements and bring down their ability to get weapons.

You might find that for the most part, people who legally obtain guns are usually responsible and socially aware people and a lot have gone through training on how to use a weapon and even more, how to be responsible as an owner of a gun.

And, to your points on marking dangerous curves etc., despite all that aren´t there still a lot of deaths caused by those who ignore and blatantly break those laws.

Sentences on illegal possession and use of weapons, better and early identification of individuals with mental illness that would make gun ownership by them dangerousto themselves and others, and getting to the root of the people problems with gun ownership is a better place to start I think.

In Europe, doctors and ER people are trained to look for signs in people they treat that could identify potential dangers and they try and get them help.

Walter, video games have nothing to do with it. Millions of kids in hundreds of countries play shooter video games. They don't go out and shoot people afterwards, even if they want to. That is because they can't get the weapons. The difference is that in the USA, they can. It's all about the access to the weapons. Without that access, even the most heinous fantasies can't become brutal reality.

The stats presented by Mr. Blow in a previous column demonstrate this: the USA is way out of whack in regard to gun death than any other industrialized nation. It also has the most widespread private gun ownership and laxest gun control laws of those nations. That's not coincidence.

No, Hollywood and video games are red herrings thrown up by the gun-nuts to distract from the truth we all recognize deep down: the problem with guns in this country is the guns.
Hunting with a gun, if successful, results in killing animals.

All the denials of the gun as a danger deny that a gun in human hands (except hunting) involves an impulse to kill. Whether the result of mental health issues, or a list of social causes, from media to video games, they converge at the use of a gun to act upon the impulse to kill. If we can not diagnose or predict the mental triggers, the dark voices that reel away morality, we can agree that the trigger of a gun, esp. assault weapons, is where impulse meets opportunity. The gun becomes the instrument for many who harbor the unpredictable, unseen urge to ignore the cost of their actions and play judge and jury.

If we can not deal with what we cannot predict, we can deal with what we can. The common factor is the gun. Over and over, it is what we know, the one point we can control.

Those who cite stats about car deaths, accidents, and other deadly forms, ignore the common use of the gun. Few die from the deliberate use of the car as an object to kill. The same with accidents and other causes. While not all guns are deliberately used to kill, the latent use is implied. More than not, it is the object of choice.

We mark dangerous curves, stop intoxicated drivers, childproof medicines, install smoke alarms to save lives. So should we prevent gun violence.

Lastly one of the leading proponents of gun ownership, died Friday, murdered in his office, surrounded by his gun collection. They didn't save him. Revolution? The dead have no rights or freedom.

A convertible in Florida raises another downside - sunburn.  I speak from experience.

The story I remember about Lee Iacocca, which may be apocryphal, was that when he took over Chrysler he asked all the top executives what their golf handicaps were.  Anyone who was nine or better was fired, under the assumption that he was spending too much time on the links rather than he office.

I recall Lee Iacocca for two things.  As the chairman of Chrysler he brought back the convertible (which went out with AC) and he borrowed $1.5 billion in 1979 guaranteed by the US Government which he repaid ahead of schedule.  At the same time the US Government guaranteed NYC debt to help bail it out.  The two were tied together in an extraordinary coalition of corporate and public sector lobbyists.  Somewhere in storage I have the Jimmy Carter thank you certificate which was handed out to everyone involved.  I believe that's now worth less than the parchment paper on which it is inscribed.

Many of the pro-gun posts on the gun control issue contain NRA talking points. I don't know what the NRA's end game is. Perhaps they won't stop until laws are passed requiring everyone to carry a weapon at all times.

Martin Weiss, as Rima Regas's post hints, I think you owe Mr. Blow an apology.

He is on your side. He is against the prison-industrial complex. He is against the cycling of young men, usually minorities, through the prison system without a fair chance at rehabilitation. He is against inhumanly long sentences. He is against paranoia, whether from hate groups or from the NRA (if itt's not one of them), and the Republican party. I guess he's against torture by government agents and hunting down whistleblowers, too, though I don't recall that he has written about them. (Maybe he has.)

Martin the flaw in your logic is that the "paranoid patriots" that Mr. Blow is writing about are the same people who vote against their own economic interests and put the people in power that enforce the policies which you criticize.

Threatening to visit violence on those who would even dare to suggest restrictions on types of weapons is tyranny itself.

The founding fathers struggled to come up with a Constitution that balances the rights of the individual and the responsibilities and powers of the government. They came up with a system of checks and balances that is the envy of the modern world. They devised a Constitutional democracy with a system of laws that eliminated the necessity of violent rebellion.

And, in fact, those who are concerned about the right to bear arms have not only had their day in court but have won impressive victories in the Supreme Court. And have convinced state legislatures and governors to permit carrying of weapons in all manner of places that used to be places of peaceable assembly. Yet despite these victories, they threaten violence as the first resort? This is not the way of a citizenry aroused to defend rights in a democracy.

Rowen,

95% of the article talks about similarities and then a few weak disclaimers were thrown in. It ends with the assertion that if we just get past the emotional rhetoric, we could come to a reasonable meeting place on both. That is equivalence. The problem is that we've already had a reasonable solution to the abortion debate, leave the moral questions to the woman and her doctor, and instead we are getting nothing but second guessing of those decisions and impediments including restrictions that close down all the clinics that support abortion. Abortion is under a steady and real attack. The same cannot be said for gun ownership.

I think that guns should be treated like cars.

Register all guns and keep a complete database easily accessible by law enforcement.

Require gun owners to get a licence which requires tests both written and practical with different tests for different kinds of guns.

Require gun owners to carry liability insurance.

Subject gun owners to a myriad of rules as to how they may operate the guns such as making it illegal to operate a gun while under the influence of alcohol.

Require regular inspections of guns.

Regulate what type of guns are legal and where various types can be used.

Have a special group of police whose sole duty is to see that gun operators obey the rules.

All 0f our freedoms are subject to retrictions. You can't falsely yell fire in a crowded theater.

Not to get into a debate on abortion rights, etc. but I'm a bit fed up with anyone who would object to having a vaginal ultrasound!  Any woman who has had sex can have a vaginal ultrasound without any discomfort whatsoever (I'm not talking about young girls who are rape victims, that is a separate issue....so please no comments on that).  I realize this is not the forum for this, but no matter what anyone says a vaginal ultrasound is an excellent, non-invasive medical examination (sorry, again, if you have had sex, it is not invasive - and in fact, it's not as invasive as a pap smear, because no one is scraping you, it's just a probe and getting a look at a much better angle) which ALL women should have every year at their annual gyn exam no matter what!
If abortion rights and gun restrictions are supported by a majority of the country then abortion rights and gun restrictions are desirable to a majority of the country.

Quote from Kevin's comment:

"And that is the point. For me it's not important what the weapon is called. For me the critical point of regulation is the capacity of the magazine. If you can't hunt legally with the firearm, then it should not be in civilian hands, period."

I was not conceding that all non-hunting rifles should be outlawed. Just disagreeing with the author's premise that the Bushmaster is not a hunting rifle. The 2nd Amendment was meant to protect an individual's right to own and carry firearms of quality and substantial capability for the defense of home and community.
The 1st and 2nd Amendments are very different: words don't kill people, but guns do.

You would lose that bet. Not an AR type rifle, or large capacity magazines. Beginning with New York County.

And legal abortions are always available in the US, never more than a Greyhound ride away.
